Posts.Content: Hello I am due to have my PICC line out on Friday. It has been in since the first week in January. Is it going to hurt, any tips anyone?
Posts.Title: PICC Line

Posts.Content: Oh thank you ladies, so glad it's not like when it's put in! I can't wait, so fed up with covering it every day for shower and wearing sleeves and wearing tubigrip and having it flushed and everything!
Posts.Title: PICC Line

Posts.Content: Tax is so tough, I have never felt so ill and lifeless in my life. From my experience I can say that the second to last was the worst, and that was with a reduced dose. The last one - last week, well, I dont know if it is the euphoroa of it being the last one but my se have not been nearly so bad. I was not only awake on Sunday but also did a Sainsburys shop, (I didnt dare drive tho, Chemo brain!). Last time I couldnt put one foot in front of the other until a full week after! My aching bones and joints have been minimal too. I had injections for 5 days rather than the one big injection after all my tax, it may be worth asking if this makes a difference to your se. Now this could all be that I was expecting the absolute worst after number 5 which was awful, however this is me. You need to make the right choice for you, however once you have made that choice, whatever it is, dont beat yourself up over it and think "what if", it will drive you crazy if you do that. I am sure you will make the right decision. All good wishes, positive thoughts and cyber hugs at this horrid time.
Posts.Title: Don't want last taxotere but will I regret it?

Posts.Content: Good girl and well done. We all have wobbly moments. You can do it!
Posts.Title: Don't want last taxotere but will I regret it?

Posts.Content: Morning! Most definitely HAD. I decided that at my two week check from surgery. They were confident they had captured it all and the chemo had killed off the cells in my lymph nodes. Start rads this week as belt and braces and already on Letrozol. Oh yes, most definitely HAD. It was one visitor that is not invited or welcome back, not in my body, oh no and not in anyone's else's either!
Posts.Title: HAD or HAVE?

Posts.Content: Hi Only Me I had my last FEC T on April 23rd, had MX and ANC on May 29th and will be starting rads in the next few weeks. I have a reasonable amount of regrowth too. Like Aroma mum I couldn't bear to have it shaved, however my hairdresser has suggested she just takes the very ends off and shapes it around my ears using comb and scissors, not clippers. I have yet to book an appointment though, I just decide to do it then change my mind thinking I will wait another week! I can't wait until I've got more hair than head and can put some colour on. I'm following this thread with interest to see what the general opinions are. Thanks for posting!
Posts.Title: Hair Regrowth

Posts.Content: Hi everyone. I had my MX and node clearance on Wednesday. I was fully expecting to be completely flat chested on one side but I'm not. Is it normal to have what I can only describe as a mini breast after surgery? That's what it looks like when I look down, which means that I have a tiny bit of cleavage which I am delighted about. I can't help thinking though that this will make my prosthesis a bit uncomfortable when the time comes. I'm wearing a "comfy" at the mo which is okay. Have any of you ladies experienced similar? Any advice would be appreciated. Thank you.
Posts.Title: Flat chest?

Posts.Content: Hi there My partner and I do not have critical illness cover but my partner does have health care insurance from his employer. Fortunately for a small additional premium he added me on to this as a named partner when we moved in together. We were advised by one of his colleagues that this cover pays us for using the NHS for oncology day patient appointments rather than using private facilities. It would be the same for any condition if we elected NHS over private. It is frustrating dealing with them never speaking or being able to speak to the same person twice, and they don't come to us to advise they need additional paperwork, we call or email them to chase and they say "oh you need to send us this" but hopefully we are nearly there. So ladies and gents, check out that paperwork and make a call, there could be a spoonful of sugar to help this medicine go down!
Posts.Title: Insurance claims

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies, I was just surprised at not being flat after surgery. Very pleased I have a cleavage though!!
Posts.Title: Flat chest?

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed on New Years Eve too! My breast went very red, the skin pitted like an orange peel and it was sore for a few days. I called my BC nurse who consulted with the onc and assured me it was proof the chemo was doing its best. However I strongly recommend you contact your support team to make sure ASAP so if you have to be examined you can be seen and on the mend before the weekend. Good luck and take care
Posts.Title: Breast lump hardened and sore during fec chemo - is this normal?

Posts.Content: Hi Mccaan I'm right with you. I've had x3 FEC and like you have got away lightly with the side effects and have my first of 3 docetaxal on Tuesday this week. It sounds horrid doesn't it! I have to take steroids twice a day for 3 days starting tomorrow then I have to inject myself after, can't remember for how long. I've resisted googling and stuck to the discussions on this site, not sure though they are any less scary but they are more trustworthy. I think all we can do is exactly the same as on FEC. Go in with an open mind and just deal with whatever it throws at us and hope to goodness we get away just as lightly! I'm not sure what effect this has on our hair. I've got some eyebrows left from FEC and eyelashes but that's it. It's weird, I'm more worried about losing those than I was about losing my hair. I've not had mx yet, I've still got that left to look forward to. Lets hope we get some positive feedback and if we do feel poorly its just for the first week like FEC. Think positive, there are loads of ladies that have been through this, we can do it!
Posts.Title: Finished fec and start tax on Wednesday but feeling really nervous...

Posts.Content: Mornin, perhaps we ought to start a breakfast club! Well the first T was fine yesterday, I actually felt better last night than I did after my FEC! No. Side effects yet, went back to work after & just getting ready to walk my dog. Probably the calm before the storm but hey ho, that's 4 down 2 to go. The chemo nurse gave me nerve pain killers to take if the joint pain kicks in but said I could take paracetamol or ibuprofen first if I didn't think it was too bad but not to hesitate to take her painkillers if I needed to. The Pre loaded syringes have to be kept in the fridge and taken out half an hour before use, recommended to inject at 4 pm as it is a little less disruptive to your sleep pattern . So all'sgood for the mo, drink loads before you go and after, I'm sure that helps!
Posts.Title: Finished fec and start tax on Wednesday but feeling really nervous...

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane. When I had my first chemo the advice was to avoid public transport, children and air conditioned environments. As others have said, your immunity will be very low after your chemo starts so I would suggest you take this time off so as to be as fit as you can be to prepare for battle! You have not got time to be poorly and fully recover by the 4th, and after mentally preparing yourself for treatment the last thing you want is for it to be delayed! Keep doing your arm exercises which will help with muscle strength and the healing should be well on the way before your chemo starts. Good luck with it all and keep posting, there is always someone here to advise on even the smallest questions!
Posts.Title: About to start chemo .a question or two..?...

Posts.Content: Hi AnneH I had a seroma after my mx. It seemed stupid that after being poised and sliced, such a small thing could get me down so much so I do sympathise with you. Unfortunately there is nothing you can do to make it go away. I used to hold my mx site when I got up from sitting or lying down, as the gush of fluid was sooo weird it made me feel quite sick sometimes. My breast unit were reluctant to drain it because of the risk of infection, when it was time for my rads planning I went into panic mode thinking I would die if rads were delayed but in the end, they just drained it every other day for rads treatment. The upside is that it gave me a cleavage, the fluid now seems to have been replaced by scar tissue and I am left with a moob, which is no problem at all and I still have a cleavage. I am just waiting for a breast reduction on my healthy breast and all will be well. Stick with it my lovely, it's just another step you will soon be over on this mountain we have to climb Tokes x
Posts.Title: Tiresome, depressing seroma

Posts.Content: Thanks ladies. I didn't know if the radiation would damage my watch. They couldn't start treatment today because my seroma pushed the measurements from the planning out of the accepted tolerance level. Back tomorrow, hey ho!
Posts.Title: Quick question - jewellery

Posts.Content: Good evening. Like others on recent posts I start rads tomorrow. I've read the literature but cannot see any reference to wearing jewellery. As it is just the chest wall being targeted, are there any rules? Thanks and good luck to all
Posts.Title: Quick question - jewellery

Posts.Content: Could someone please explain. Reading on this site many ladies have just partial lymph node clearance. I am having FEC-T and am scheduled to have mx late May. When I had my first biopsy the node results were inconclusive. Another biopsy was done and cancerous cells were found. I then had a full body bone scan and a CT scan to see if any cells had gone AWOL, all clear thankfully. From then on in all discussions I am having a full node clearance. How do they know already that I need this, or is it that different oncologists just have different views and some examine at the time of surgery and some just get rid if there has been any trace of cancer cells? I'm an "if it ain't broke don't fix it" kinda girl, however if there would even be an outside chance of dormant cells.nestling in my nodes then I'm all for taking them all! I'm just confused at the different procedures offered. Any advice would be appreciated, thank you
Posts.Title: Lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: Thank you Kate. I am on the heavy side too so perhaps there is a link. I will ask at the next opportunity. I just worry that with no nodes on that side I will be susceptible to more issues. On this site there is a diagram of lymph nodes and it looks like a string from the neck finish in the underarm area, perhaps they will leave that one in. This is an adventure that's for sure and the steepest learning curve I have ever experienced. Thank goodness for all you ladies that have a wealth of knowledge to share. I hope I will be able to support others as you do once I am enjoying the view from this mountain I am climbing!
Posts.Title: Lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: Morning IreneK My word you have been through it, we'll done on your recovery from 7 years ago. I'm not able to help with having BC twice with all positive LN, but I can send you a (((hug))) which at this time in the morning may at least secure a couple of hours sleep. There will be someone on this site that can offer some support I'm sure. Hang on in there and draw strength from the fact you have kicked cancers butt once, you can do it again. Take care
Posts.Title: Help Please

Posts.Content: Hello. I'm trying not to panic but I've just noticed a stitch coming out of my scar. I had my MX and ANC on May 29th and a seroma developed a week ago which is very uncomfortable. Has anyone else had a stitch come through and if so what was done about it please?
Posts.Title: Stitch coming through scar

Posts.Content: Oh bless you, it's horrid when things change and don't go to plan. I am having FEC-T, had 5/6 this week before mx and immediate reconstruction. I had my dose of docetaxal reduced by 25%, I was really concerned! However I spoke to my onc and he assured me that because of my sensitivity to tax, I was neutropenic and in hospital for 4 days, reducing the dose was the right thing to do and it was a well trodden path. There is an effective margin where they can increase and decrease as necessary without compromising the effectiveness. I feel loads better this time too, hopefully you will too. Good luck and try not to worry. Take care x
Posts.Title: Changed dose of FEC ...will it still be effective !!??

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies. It's not nice is it but good to know it has happened to others too. I thought the seroma was pushing it through and was scared I would come undone! Goodness the mind goes onto overdrive at the least little thing when you are going through all this treatment. Many thanks and have a good weekend.
Posts.Title: Stitch coming through scar

Posts.Content: Oh my goodness you poor love. Firstly, we have to be guided by the professionals, they have been doing this for years and we are relatively new to this shitty journey. I do understand your devastation tho because since the beginning you have been advised one thing, made a plan in your head, organised your life around that plan and then bang, suddenly there is no plan any more. From the beginning I was told I could have an immediate recon with my MX, then Mr Plastic said I had to wait a year for it. Like you I am a big girl up top and I was devastated that for a year I am going to be lopsided at best, no cleavage and stuck with a prosthesis. I was not happy. My partner understood my frustration but not the extent of it. He doesn't care what I look like, he's just glad I'm here to tell the tale. I'm sure that's what your husband means, he just can't express it properly. Men don't get it, but sometimes we forget they have been thru hell too and to them, uneven boobs is a small price to pay to still have us alive. I have to say tho, the "it's a small price to pay" comments don't wash with me too well. I know that, don't need to hear it when all I want is to have a cleavage and 2 boobs! When you get over the shock you will feel a little better about it. Still as mad as hell but a little better. You might not need a full size prosthesis, just enough to give you a lift. Whatever you have, you will learn to live with it because that's what we do. As if having BC is not enough to emotionally deal with we then have physical stuff to deal with too, and because we are larger busted ladies, it seems insurmountable at times. But you know what, we can do it,. We have been through the nasty stuff, we just have to learn to think differently to get through this bit. Cyber hugs to you {{{{{{{hugs}}}}}}}
Posts.Title: BREAST REDUCTION AFTER RADS
